Comment: WW

See my previous posts on this subject. 

I am not opposed to nuclear power, I am not opposed to wind or solar if it isn't subsidized.  I am not opposed to natural gas development or generating electricity with it. 

But I am opposed to Site C for all the reasons I pointed out. 

In fact, the Peace Region has great potential for wind generated power and has four large wind generating projects already producing power (Bear Mountain, Quality Ridge, Dokie Ridge & Meikle Ridge. Combined capacity of 560MW) and more in the planning stage including one just south of the Site C construction site. 

http://www.edf-en.ca/project/taylor-wind/

This project will be 250-400MW. This is 20-35% the capacity of Site C.

Comment: The right to marry & form a family is a fundamental human right enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (Article 16), and the equal right to access to, and protection by, the law and all parts of it are enshrined in the nation's constitution.

Opposing those rights without a single rational justification for that opposition, is an act of irrationally discriminating against (or seeking the discrimination against) homosexuals.

The definition of homophobia (Merriam Webster dictionary) is as follows:
IRRATIONAL fear of, aversion to, OR DISCRIMINATION AGAINST homosexuality or homosexuals

If the action meets the definition of homophobia, then the action is homophobic.
The only possible way to change that fact is to redefine the word homophobia and get the new definition of the word accepted and adopted by a sufficient proportion of the population to warrant the redefinition being adopted by each set of authors & editors of each version of the dictionary

Comment: The historian Peter Gay, writing about the end of the Enlightenment (in his amazing two-volume work), said that Europe "lost its nerve." People lost confidence that they could work rationally to solve problems, that they could mine the creativity of the populace, that they could work in some combination of togetherness and individuality to overcome the sad and tragic patterns of history that seemed to enslave countries and dictate events, the oppression of king and Church, the wasting of human talent and potential, the squandering of initiative and enthusiasm, and achieve victory over ignorance and lack of broad education. I see this verdict applying to the U.S. and to much of the world now, Western democratic countries in particular. There is a loss of nerve. It's as if everyone has given up, across broad bands of society. There is no trust in clear thinking and respectful pooling of ideas.

As for the company holding shares of another company, that is a legal means of tax avoidance in Canada.



nelligan.ca/article/understanding-holding-companies/

A holding company is a company that owns shares in another company. If the holding company owns the majority of shares of another company, it is also referred to as a parent company. It generally does not produce goods or services itself. The sole purpose of a holding company is usually to own shares in another company.

Comment: Theological illiteracy among Catholics can be blamed, at least in part, on the culture of paternalism within the Church. The hierarchy still supports a top-down method of pedagogy, even for adults. (Even the word "pedagogy" implies a model of learning suited to children.) If that's the system one is formed in, it doesn't make for robust adult faith but, rather, theological dependency. 

As for Scriptural illiteracy, until the mid-20th century, Catholics were discouraged from individual reading of the Bible. The idea was that the laity weren't equipped to understand Scripture without the help of the clergy, and that our time to be nourished with The Word of God was during the homily at Mass. The Church still holds that homiletics is the primary mode of Scriptural catechesis for adults. The problem is that too little emphasis is placed in seminary formation on good homiletics, and it shows.

Jesus played with the children and taught the adults. We do it the other way around.

Comment: "Unfortunately, theres no way to actually improve health care when you start from that paradigm."--"Improving healthcare" is misleading.  We have some of the best healthcare facilities and doctors in the world, and EMTALA forbids providers from turning away those seeking treatment.  The real issue is the multi-decade double-digit increases in healthcare costs--which can be resolved quite easily via the enforcement of existing anti-trust and consumer protection legislation, as well as a mandate on price transparency and consent to services.  The fact that our current leaders of both parties are seeking to implement new, money-wasting bureaucracies instead of demanding prosecution of monopolistic practices as allowed by existing law should be evidence enough that they don't want to solve the problem.

Comment: Here's the thing.  The point about people in similar situations paying the same amount is fair.

Problem is that this government has gotten away with redefining "fair" entirely on their own terms.  Sure it isn't fair that someone using a professional corp can reduce takes from 53.53% and someone else can't,  but the issue is the 53.53% tax rate that applies to the other guy, not the use of the professional corporation.  That tax rate kicking in at 220k is fundamentally offensive. 

Same thing with income "sprinkling".  Sure it isn't fair that a married couple that can income split through a professional corp pays less tax than a couple that can't use a corp, but the fix isn't found in closing loopholes to raise more money, it is in eliminating the rank unfairness of forcing a married couple earning 200k on 1 salary to pay way more tax than a married couple earning 200k on 2 salaries.  refusing to treat households as a single unit is among the most unfair things we could possibly do.

Comment: No, it doesn't.  If you don't know what you're talking about, best to keep quiet.  Bundled loans in the US were made up of hundreds (sometimes thousands) of loans, and sold off in individual investments to institutional and private investors for their income stream. They were sold as high quality, when in fact they were not.  That is fraud, and is not even close to what is being referred to as a "bundled" mortgage in the article.  You try to sound smart, but you are clueless.  The bundle here in Canada is simply a first mortgage from a conventional lender, and a second mortgage from a private lender like a MIC. The private lender takes the risk, that CMHC or another insurer used to take. The private lender takes 100% of the risk on their investment.  They could lose it all, and the taxpayer won't be helping them out.  The borrower is fully aware of the transaction, and it works well for them because they get the majority at a lower rate, and the second mortgage is more expensive.

The Republican party, traditionally associated with a hawkish stance toward Moscow, threw its support behind a presidential candidate who openly called on Russia to hack his opponent’s campaign.

Majority leader Mitch McConnell told Obama and leading Democrats that he would regard any effort to release evidence of Russian interference before the election as partisan. In other words, he put his own party’s interest in electing Trump ahead of the national interest.

Comment: This story is a perfect example of the difficulty facing doctors when deciding what to prescribe. Many people with chronic illness function very well on traditional treatment. They are not pain-free but they are able to live and come to terms with the pain they have. A small percentage with exactly the same illness are unable or unwilling to do so. 
The problem with narcotics is that they work beautifully. It doesn't matter whether you have headaches, back pains or joint pains, narcotics will be better than anything you ever tried before. But it comes with huge costs. If you take it for life you WILL be addicted. Addiction is a physical change at cellular level in the body whereby normal metabolism requires the addictive substance. The writer may be doing well now, but she is addicted whether she believes it or not, and as tolerance develops, fentanyl will become less effective so increasing doses will be required, eventually to dangerous levels. This is why it shortens lives.

Comment: The recent Home Capital issue illustrates a new kind of problem.  The loan book appears to be solid, but depositors are reluctant to back it for the poor returns on offer.  This problem is a more general structural one across the housing market, and even the entire economy.  Low interest rates stimulate borrowing, but also increase risk, and reduce the incentive to invest, all at the same time. The solution is to raise interest rates, to a) properly reward investors, and b) deter risky lending in the housing market due to the 'free money' atmosphere that's been created.  If I'm wrong, please tell me how.

Comment: While I have no particular issue with your analysis or conclusion that the current system is not particularly effective, I strongly disagree with the statement that; … we can use the tax system to encourage more mothers to work``. When did it become an accepted truth that more mothers should work? Mothers (and Fathers) should be encouraged to do what is in the best interests of their children. In fact, this is a key test in divorce proceedings to ensure that the interests of the children are not only recognized, but become a primary factor in designing individual plans of arrangement.

Before we all accept as fact that institutionalizing child rearing and having more mothers in the workforce is the best outcome for our society, I would like to see some real debate on the subject that focuses on what is in the best long term interest of our children and ultimately, therefore, in the best long term interest of society. 
 
We might be surprised at the answer.

Comment: Rent control was lifted for apartments built post 1991,  not those built before 1991.   So,  rent control existed for the full 42 years.  The effect of the introduction of rent control was to send a chill down any developers spine.   If you built a building post 1991,  you put a condo plan on it and sold the units.  Holding it long term as a rental building would put you at risk of expropriation without compensation by future government fiat (exactly what rent control represents).     The proof is in the numbers,  developers stopped building in 1975,  and have not even considered building again until very recently.     The development community needed a long time for the economics to justify building,  and a future generation to forget how vulnerable you are in Ontario is you build rental.    This debate has already reminded the development community that the Ontario government cannot be trusted.    A lot of harm has been done in the last few weeks.

Comment: Sort of.  Legality doesn't make something just or unjust.  For example, slavery was legal once but it's legality certainly didn't make it just.  Abortion is extraordinarily unjust, yet it is legal.
Justice demands that the punishment fit the crime.  Theft is not a capital offense.  To execute a thief would be highly unjust.  But a murder warrants capital punishment.
That's not to suggest that vengeance is justice.  Vengeance in this case would be to torture and abuse the murderer in the same manner he mistreated his victims.  Executing him humanely is justice, not vengeance.
Justice requires that the punishment fit the crime, that he is allowed a fair trial, that he is given time to think about his crime/repent, and that the execution be carried out swiftly and as painlessly as possible - things not given to his victims.

Comment: Not to disagree but worth noting 4/6 lane divided highways are engineered to sustain an 80 mph rate of travel. 65 mph is arbitrary, based in large part on fuel efficiency, and really too low for most highways. Which is why 70-75 speeds aren't usually punished. In fact, a large safety problem with too low limits is that something like 90% of drivers will travel at the safe rate of speed for any given highway, which is usually higher than the speed limit. Thus those travelling the posted rate are as dangerous to safe travel as the few exceeding the actual safe rate, if they don't stay in the right lane when available so as not to impede traffic. Doubling down on too low limits is a lost cause as you're fighting human nature and the actual design of the roads. 

Physical calming measures work in neighborhoods by impacting the physics. If we want highway speeds to match lower arbitrary limits we need to stop designing 80 mph highways.

Regulation is always a problem but regulations are always changing as project technical elements and stakeholder interests change. This project would have succeeded regardless the regulations if the economics were sound. Perhaps the delay was a good thing.

I am reminded of the rush to ship LNG through BC ports over the last few years. There were as many as 20 competing proposals. Now, because the price of gas in Asia is so low none will be built. Regulatory delays may have saved us from financial disaster.

All things considered TRP made the right decision for the right reasons. They can always come back at a later date and revisit this project, if the economics change.

Comment: The Ottomans did not make serious attempts to invade Western Europe. Their Sultan explicitly told Kara Mustafa not to invade Vienna, and if he attempted to do so, and failed, he would have to kill himself with  a royal cord. 

The Ottomans ruled over most of the former Roman Empire. In the Roman Empire, 9 of the 10 largest cities were in the Middle East and Turkey. Not in Western Europe. This has to do with the fertile soils of the Nile, Tigris, Euphrates, etc. Back then agriculture occupied 90 percent of the working population.

The increases of population in Europe were of the poor and starving. For example, the Irish left after the Potato Famine. It wasn't a sign of their success, but of their poverty and overpopulation.

In history, the poor have almost always emigrated to richer countries. That was the reason that hundreds of thousands of Brits went to India from the 16th to the 19th centuries. Same reason no Indians went in the other direction.

Comment: The employer group plans cover more and for less than if you went out and bought your own plan (even before Obamacare), so you would not be smart to pass that up. If you get insurance on your own, you will not have much control over that either. The insurers and doctors will dictate what you can cover and for how much based on your family history, and any pre-existing conditions you have. Doctors will not take patients from plans they do not know and plans that have very limited coverage. You may go to the doctor and find you have a condition that costs a lot for drugs and care-- doctors do not want to have the sick patient not be covered by his policy and be unable to pay his bill. Doctors do not take patients with no insurance for a similar reason-- you could develop a condition requiring treatment that costs $50,000 to $100,000 or much, much more and the doctor does not want to find out you cannot afford that.

Comment: Some people still don't get it.  This is a demographic phenomena that won't disappear until the last of the baby boomers is well into his 90s.

Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, baby boomers, in their youth, swamped the system, increasing aggregate demand, and forcing double digit interest rates and sky-high inflation on the economy.  Some thought this was the new norm, but it was aided by a significant demographic blip.

Now, all of these baby boomers are hitting retirement, and the reverse is happening.  Aggregate demand is decreasing, baby boomers are downsizing, and negative inflation (or deflation) is a real threat.... yet some people still don't get it... thinking that the 1970s and 1980s must repeat, irrespective of the demographic situation.

Low interest rates are going to be here for a very long time, as the last of the baby boomers won't be in his 90s until around 2040. Quit all this bellyaching about some sort of "conspiracy", and learn to adjust to the current realities!

Comment: Seems like the city could hire a full time driver for a water truck. 
It goes to show the good Lord didn't design Alaska for cars and four-wheelers, I guess. Maybe summer would be a good time to encourage the use of bicycles and also walking. In the olden days the Ahtna people were semi-nomadic and walked hundreds of miles all year around, from the Wrangells to Denali. They followed caribou, moose and salmon. Trails were wide and deeply worn from between five  and seven thousand years of use. So walking in Alaska is not out of the question. 
Back in the 90s we had a huge problem with dust which was deposited as volcanic ash all across the Copper Valley. That stuff blew around for five years afterward! We were told it was five times as hard as steel and it got into and destroyed our cars, our electronic equipment and a lot of residents now have COPD. Interestingly, the ash contained so many nutrients that the trees literally shot up! Areas that were open years ago are now forested.

Comment: Yes but we must also accept that there will be pain as a part of the normal aging process. it was big Pharma that started promoting about 2 decades ago that pain should be completely eliminated from people's lives. This is not realistic, and leads to the situation we have today. 

Pain should be managed and lived with using medications we already have until the condition becomes unbearable, which should only happen when a condition is inoperable.  Bone grinding on bone in a hip is unbearable. People need to get these surgeries faster. Nerve pain can be managed with other drugs, so can muscle pain, with physio, massage, chiropractic, yoga and staying active. Comment: WorkBC's report has indicated that we will need over 22,000 new teachers by 2022 - most BC teachers are rather old and are retiring in ever-increasing numbers; rather like the current mass-hiring, if we do not find ways to have the supply of teachers meet demand, we will have an even worse situation as time goes by. PostMedia did a survey last week of job postings, and came up with over 900 unfilled contracts, and a need for nearly 1000 on-call teachers on top. That's a lot.

Speaking completely empirically, BC offers the worst starting salary for a teacher outside of Quebec (which has lower standards); the gap between a new BC teacher and one elsewhere can be as much as $10,000 to $20,000. Add on BC's high cost of living, and we just aren't bringing in enough teachers. Raising the starting salary would incentivize new teachers to come to BC, instead of staying in the other provinces.

If you don't like the proposed solutions, what are your alternatives?

Comment: Re. Voting B.C. style

Despite what this letter says, BC has never voted on a true system of proportional representation but rather on a form of instant run-offs, the single transferable vote. The latter system does not guarantee proportionality and is, at best, a slight improvement over first past the post. 

Many countries using PR systems do, in fact, have stable governments, including Germany and New Zealand (both of which used mixed-member proportional representation). PR would encourage voters to vote according to their conscience rather than thinking strategically about who has the best chance of winning. Isn't that how democracy is supposed to work?

Comment: I wonder if anyone who believes the Republican/conservative meme that the poor are simply lazy and don't want to work have seen the BBC series "Slum House" on PBS. Selected individuals and families are experiencing poverty in London through a new decade every week. This week they graduated from the 1880s to the 1890s. They are working their behinds off just to survive, and as each decade brings improvements they still work harder than ever, a few doing better but most not quite making enough and some failing despite their efforts.

There are some big lessons from this despite the artificial circumstances of this historical reality show. But even more instructive is the historical narration. As London grew and immigration increased, income disparity accelerated. Government in the 1890s finally began to take a few small steps to improve life for the poor.

But how do you think the well off and wealthy began to perceive the poor? I'll give you one guess.

Comment: First, it's important to keep things in perspective and get a grip. PERS is in excellent shape. See this recent report from Bloomberg: www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2017-state-pension-funding-ratios/  Next look up what "unfunded liability" really means. It is not how much PERS actually owes or how far behind it is. Then consider that PERS has been reformed (benefits reduced) over 20 times since 1995. That includes two big structural transformations. A lot has been done in Oregon by many people. That's why we're in such good shape compared to so many others. The unions were willing to go even further this time, and made a proposal that many public employees opposed. It was a good offer. All it needed was some concessions on corporate taxes, but the major business interests would not budge an inch. If we're going to make things work, we all have to pitch in. Public employees are not the only ones responsible for floating this boat.

Comment: Immunity is specific to the testimony you give.  

If Michael Flynn gives testimony with specific immunity and someone wants to punish him, they would simply prosecute him for 'trumped up' charges based on something other than that testimony.  No immunity can protect a person from false charges if someone is determined to do that.

A grant of immunity is, however, effective is in protecting you from conviction for the crimes you're going to give evidence on.

So no, there really is no reason to seek immunity if you don't think the evidence you're about to give has a good chance of leading to your conviction.  The reasons to grant immunity are clear - his evidence will lead to the conviction of someone even more important.

My subject was Vancouver, and the extremely high house prices there ARE the result of a flood of overseas money flooding in since the late 1980s, mainly from rich folks born and raised in Hong Kong and mainland China. That mechanism is the reason that houses in Vancouver skyrocketed to dozens of times the average annual local income in Vancouver. That mechanism is the reason why a small house on a small lot in Vancouver sells for two million dollars.

You pretend that my recognition of facts and reality is somehow "racist". 

Nope, it is not racist to recognize reality. Canada COULD have accepted the same number of immigrants from Hong Kong and China but in economic groups similar to those in Canada: many lower middle class, many middle class, some poor, a few very rich. That would have been excellent and house prices in Vancouver would not have skyrocketed. But instead Canada selected for ultra-rich millionaires, resulting in two million dollar little bungalows.

Comment: The professor is absolutely right in at least one important respect.  Those with foreign sounding names - - Asian, Arabic , Indian, Pakistani and many others - -  are FAR less likely to be hired  or even interviewed despite their qualifications.    That is a fact of life in Canada and it has  been made even easier  in the computer age.  Back in the day, applicants were able to knock on doors and fill out applications and  present resumes AT the company seeking employees, sometimes through the human resources staff who could evaluate them on a personal level.  Today, the vast majority of job applicants must send  a cover letter and resume ON LINE. That makes it easier to weed out the "foreigners"  from the French, British, Irish etc.and then simply send them  form rejection letters while wishing them luck in their future endeavors.      Is there anyone who doesn't understand how this process  works.

Comment: I have to say that I am always amazed at the amount of vitriol that always emerges in articles like this one. I always considered myself a feminist- and I am very old. I grew up in the fifties- and was shocked at some of  the social mores around at the time. 
What we wanted was equal rights- to our own jobs, (without having to resign if married and/or pregnant), equal pay for equal work, the right to have credit in your own name, the right to maternity leave, the right to contraception and abortion, the right to adopt children, and so forth.
Many of those goals have been achieved- although  I do remember a man in my graduate class saying, "Remember, we won't give up power- you might have to just take it".
Perhaps I am just mellowing with age, I am still angered by  injustice .
However, I certainly don't understand the vicious criticism hurled at Sophie Gregoire when she points out the need to include men and boys in our journey towards understanding.
Why can't we support one another?.

Comment: When the court is wrong, particularly in a matter where its own credibility is at stake, it must act to correct the situation in order to sustain its legitimacy. That it did so in this case is creditable, although it raises concerns about Justice Wagner's impartiality. Properly, I believe he should now recuse himself on the matter. I doubt that the court acted in response to a Twitter campaign. A lot of cases the SCC has considered have generated considerable public anger and controversy. The extraordinary decision to reverse course was in this case taken because the exclusion of LGBTQ intervenors in a matter fundamentally relevant to discrimination against members of the LGBTQ community was vastly contrary to the concepts of judicial impartiality and objectivity. After all, the SCC has to promote and protect the impartiality, and thus the legitimacy, of the Canadian legal system and its own role in it.

Comment: The blame for this issue lies squarely with the companies providing these plans, and with governments that aid and abet them. Let's be clear: the underfunding problem comes about because companies fail to meet their legal obligations to fund the plans which they themselves have agreed to (or, in some cases, generously offered) to their employees. They do this in lean years because it hurts their bottom line; and governments have colluded in this by legally allowing companies to delay payments to these plans, under the cover of providing 'financial flexibility' (and worsened the situation by allowing companies to raid pension plans when they are 'overfunded'.) The result is that poorly-performing companies get deeper and deeper into the pension fund hole, not because these plans are too expensive, but because the companies have availed themselves of the opportunity not to fund them. Place the blame where it belongs, and stop blaming workers, public or private.

Comment: Hello Waterfront10 - Sorry but what you stated does not seem accurate. Can you please post a link to an article that explains this borrowing practice? When a person gets a loan, even from a secondary lender, they will have to provide their SIN. This will connect the loan to their credit history, which banks will pull before lending any money. The more debt a person has the less loan they will be qualified for, so the loan acquired to pay the down payment will affect the amount of home that a bank will finance. For ex, if a person finds a $1 million home and goes to secondary lender for the 20% down payment ($200,000), the bank will not finance the $800,000 due to the increased debt load the person has. The person will need to find a different home that is much less than $1 million, probably between $800,000 and $900,000. This is why financial professionals always recommend that people pay off debt before attempting to buy a home, since they will qualify for a higher mortgage.

Comment: The Canadian Jewish Congress and others were attacking a number of things: freedom of speech, legal rights and common decency.

The event was a memorial for Barbara Kulaszka, who passed away a month ago. As a lawyer she defended some far-right Canadians on free speech matters. As far as I know, her views and speech have never been at issue. By attempting to shut down this memorial, its critics aren't attacking hate speech, they're attacking someone's ability to speak about a deceased person. The critics are likewise attacking the legal right to be represented by a lawyer, because the condemnation has a chilling effect on the ability of an accused to get legal representation. And then finally, the critics are attacking common decency. It was a memorial, not a neo-Nazi Holocaust-denying free for all.

Like it or not, Ms. Kulaszka defended free speech and individuals other lawyers wouldn't touch. The CJC et al acted poorly in trying to stop her memorial.

By deselecting LGBTQ intervenors in a case where LGBTQ rights and interests are fundamental to the matter at hand, the SCC's original position failed the test of objectivity. Imagine if the SCC were to hear and rule on an appeal application about a pipeline in northern Canada after deselecting intervenors representing aboriginal interests. It just wouldn't happen. And it shouldn't happen, just as it shouldn't in a case where LGBTQ interests as well as the legitimate right of LGBTQ citizens/residents to be protected from discrimination are at stake. This is not about special interests. It's about the right of people from a historically oppressed community to be able to protect themselves from discrimination. To shut them out of the process would have transformed the SCC into little more than a kangaroo court.

Comment: Very few doctors have an income of $300,000, so you're generalizing, which makes you feel better but doesn't say much about the current issues. Most doctors bill OHIP for 300 K or more, but that's like saying that your mechanic must be earning 500 K a year because that's how much the garage made in customer billings that year. Most doctors are earning at least 100 K before taxes, and a few earn more than 500 K, but a discussion of what doctors earn can't be based upon what they bill OHIP, but of what they themselves earn after they've paid their staff salaries, their equipment maintenance, their rent, etc. There are serious issues with the way medicine is practiced and paid for in Ontario, and these issues should be addressed, but don't be fooled into thinking that the problem is simply that all or even most doctors are paid too much. That may be what Wynne's gov't wants you to think, but the problems are a lot more extensive than that.

Comment: Hello small voice,

I am not debating trivial semantics. The definitions of words are fundamentally important. 

You remark that there is "gratuitous murder" and "terror" involved in the Las Vegas incident.

Look, there was also gratuitous murder and terror involved in the Sandy Hook school shooting, but that emphatically was not terrorism, for the reasons outlined in my post, above.

There was terror involved in the Chernobyl nuclear melt down, but that emphatically was not terrorism.

There was gratuitous murder in the serial killings of Jack the Ripper, but that emphatically was not terrorism.

There was gratuitous murder multiple post office workplace slayings of recent decades, also not terrorism.

The 2009 Fort Hood shooting was also not terrorism, that shooter was specifically targeting uniformed soldiers. That could be classified as an insurrection or a rebellion or an act of war, any of which would be more accurate, conceptually, than labeling it "terrorism".

Comment: First, what Ontario is doing is not universal basic income. It is just a glorified unemployment insurance scheme because it claws back fifty cents of every dollar earned by employed recipients. Like unemployment insurance and other welfare programs this claw-back provision is what destroys the incentive to work.  With universal basic income EVERY citizen receives a monthly check.  There is no means testing. Because there is no means testing there are few administrative costs.  Also, because payments are not affected by employment income, everyone still has a strong incentive to work and better their lot in life.  Keep in mind that universal basic income would replace all forms of welfare including unemployment insurance and old age security. The savings to government would be huge. More importantly UBI is a way for lower income workers to maintain dignity and self-respect.  Artists would be free to do their thing.  Crime is likely to fall.  UBI could solve a lot of problems..

Comment: "The Persian Gulf" is a big chunk of ocean and most current reports don't give anywhere enough specificity to make a judgment call on this.  The Daily Mail's article does have a graphic labeled "US Navy Handout" that shows an arrow and dot in the Strait of Hormuz.  Assume, for now, that's accurate.

Let's boil down a complicated history and set of claims.  Both Oman and Iran claim 12-mile territorial water boundaries, the effect of which is to leave no "international waters" in the Strait.  The US has not recognized these claims, and asserts the right of its warships to transit the Strait at will without giving notice.  The end result is basically a "might makes right" situation.

Almost all the recent confrontations have occurred in these disputed waters, but the exact location is critical.  Until then, we need to be careful about thumping our chests and threatening retaliation, because Iran does have the same right as any other nation to control its own waters.

Comment: Having observers on scene collecting data helps insure the viability of fisheries. Having current and historical data on fisheries is a win all the way around. Ive been long lining on boats where there aren't enough bunks to go around when an observer is on and we'll "hot bunk" it. No one has complained because they  knew that the data observers collect is important. Ive been set netting and have had to take observers out to pick the gear with us, it was no biggie at all. Most observers bend over backwards to stay out of the way and not hinder a fisher trying to make a living. Its actually nice to have someone different around to chat with and hear some different stories. From what I've seen, people who care about the future of fishing aren't bothered by taking observers on small vessel. Oh and the state doesn't pay for the observers fyi.

Comment: "Should they somehow feel more guilty than car dealership employees who sold a car to a person who later drove drunk and killed people?"
That nonsense again? Let's not mince words: Guns are made to shoot people and animals. That's their only use (unless you want to use the butt of your S&W 9mm as a hammer).
A car is made to haul people or goods. A brick is made to construct a sidewalk or wall. Cars and bricks can be used to kill, but that's not their intended use. A gun is used correctly when it kills or injures a human being (or animal).
With that said, I agree the shop that sold the guns should not be liable in any way, nor should their employees feel guilty. They sold the weapon in full compliance of all applicable laws, so how a buyer uses it isn't their fault.
For the record, I'm not a Democrat or a liberal or a gun-grabber, and I support gun ownership, but I'm not willing to listen or read any strawman nonsense.

Comment: A lot of the tension that surrounds immigration and safety, and accusations of xenophobia, are because of seemingly unequal application of the principal that is being used to push "extreme vetting". For instance, in 2014, a little less than 10,000 people in the United States died in car accidents where a driver was drunk. This is a MUCH more likely way to be injured than by an immigrant, refugee, etc. Why is there not the same logic being applied to this risk of injury? Or to many others?

Comment: If you think you're protected because you drink bottled water – think again.

The truth is about 40 percent of bottled water is regular tap water.

And it gets even worse because while large public water suppliers must test for contaminants up to seven times a day, private bottlers need only test for contaminants once a week, once a year, or once every four years, depending on the contaminant.

In fact, contaminant testing on over a hundred different bottled waters have turned up chemicals like arsenic and carcinogenic compounds, fluoride (a dangerous bone poison), the toxic metal antimony, disinfection byproducts like THMs, and pharmaceutical drugs.

To add insult to injury, the chemicals that leach out of bottled water's plastic packages are also highly toxic.

Best to get a reverse osmosis water filtration system ($340 -top of the line) new filter every year and use a BPA free reusable bottle. Also join the Environmental Defenders! Stop Nestle and others from taking our water!!

Comment: Thanks for the link. Reading it shows that large predators help BALANCE prey populations, helping keep them from damaging their habitats via overpopulation. So, if we practice active large predator removal in Alaska we can expect unbalanced prey populations to develop that damage their habitats. So the predators, whether human or large carnivores, are good for their prey populations as they skim off the excess, the concept of compensatory mortality (if the predator/hunter doesn't get them, a certain percentage over the carrying capacity will die to other factors like disease, etc.). So this supports my contention perfectly - healthy prey populations depend on healthy predator populations. So that begs the question - why would Congressman Young want to support predator control on federal lands when there is no science supporting it? His proposal is bad public policy and should be defeated.

"State spending has . been reduced to the same level as 10 years ago" - FALSE, '07 spend=$7B, '17 budget=$9.7B. Why pick '07? oil price in '07 was ~$63/bbl and rising, today its capped by shale operators' breakeven <$60. Comment: There is a lot of info missing from this story. Predator control isn't an easy thing to accomplish, especially in Alaska. Most of this refuge is roadless an inaccessible . Comment: Explain climate deniers and the four Tillamook burns,  or the Silverton Hills Fire,  of 1860s,  that burned 900,000 acres.  Was that a climate deal?  When,  in your memory,  has Oregon NOT had at least a month and as many as four months,  of little or no rain in summer and high temperatures.  If the temp sets a record by one degree,  breaking a record from 1910,  which thermometer was dependable and not now in the middle of the asphalt and cement jungle?  Eugene's temps were measured in an Almadore like countryside a century ago.  And the same for Phoenix and Los Angeles.  There are  no reliable comparisons,  and on that people want to base "science."  

I have on my lap "Climatology of the United States" by Lorin Blodget,  1857. Pub by Lippincott,  Phila.  160 year old climate records going back into the 1830s, and earlier. Across the U.S.,  taken regularly at court houses,  colleges,  high schools.  And collated into amazing maps by Blodget.   Also rainfall records for same time.

Comment: Given the limited # of characters it is, as even you might appreciate, impossible to "TELL THE WHOLE STORY."

In brief, Lincoln had an array of threats, from secessionists in the Border States to abolitionists who felt that he wasn't doing enough, to numerous politicians and journalists who were highly critical of his choices to lead the Northern Armies.  Burnside, Pope, McClellan, Hooker, Rosecrans gave plenty of ammunition to those who believed that Lincoln was unfit to be president.

When these journalists made too many overtures about making peace with the South, or gave up information which Lincoln thought could benefit the South, or found too much fault after disasters such as Fredericksburg or Chancellorsville, Lincoln had them jailed.  Estimates range from 2K - 15K.

It's important to note also that Lincoln was also a scofflaw regarding Habeus Corpus. Prior to 1863 only Congress could withhold it, but as the Merryman case proved, Lincoln again ignored the law for his own ends.

Comment: Here's the question.

Is the humanitarian aid provided by the Trump Administration, necessary for the health and safety of the people of Puerto Rico, commensurate in dollar figures, personnel response, and federal resources provided, to what the Trump Administration provided/is providing to the Houston area and Florida.

Obviously, you start with a determination of the scope of damage and the issues geography imposes (e.g. a Cat 5 Hurricane is bigger than a Cat 3; an isolated island poses limitations in individual(s) options for fleeing hurricane damaged areas).

Then, you evaluate the need based on those two things.  

Then you evaluate the place's ability to address the potential harms caused by those two things based on the conditions the place's government has prepared for and the resources strategically placed or serendipitously present to address the needs.

Has, in light of those things, the Trump Administration's response to Puerto Rico been commensurate with hat to Tx. and Fla

Comment: The former NDP government and its elected urban members did not understand or want to learn about good forest management. A mature pine forest regenerates itself through fire, even if the forest is in a provincial park. A mature pine forest MUST burn or be logged. The  Tweedsmuir South Provincial was the cause of Canada biggest natural disaster & the fires this summer. The former NDP would not let natural or prescribed burns deal with the mature pine forest. Logging was not allowed as it was a park. Nature sent in the pine beetle.

Unfortunately the beetle did not stay in the park. It destroyed thousands of square miles of forest in the BC interior. The accessible pine killed trees were logged. The inaccessible pine trees burned this year,long dead bone dry trees waiting for a hot dry summer.

The amount of carbon released by the dead trees & the fires make the Alberta oilsands look like midgets. The NDP is worried about a crude oil leak & ignores a major environmental disaster.

Comment: All I have to say is that Gary Mason has no clue what he is talking about.  The vast majority of what he says is nothing more than unsupported speculation.  There is no data to support his hypothesis that speculation is driving up condominium prices.  Condominium prices have only  increased at half the rate of single family homes (based on MLS resale data).
The problem is a lack of supply of available land for the development of new housings.  There is lots of land designated for detached and semi-detach housing, but until all the services are in, the municipality has approved the development and, the big one actually issued building permits, that land is not available. 
BTW, there is absolutely nothing wrong with buying condominiums for rental purposes.  In fact, over the last 5 years about 60% of all condos have been purchased for rental purposes in the GTA (see CMHC data).  Without the condos there would be almost no new rental housing.  Thanks to rent controls, that will dry up to.

Comment: ‘No Way To Prevent This,’ Says Only Nation Where This Regularly Happens

LAS VEGAS—In the hours following a violent rampage in Las Vegas in which a lone attacker killed more than 50 individuals and seriously injured 400 others, citizens living in the only country where this kind of mass killing routinely occurs reportedly concluded Monday that there was no way to prevent the massacre from taking place. “This was a terrible tragedy, but sometimes these things just happen and there’s nothing anyone can do to stop them,” said Iowa resident Kyle Rimmels, echoing sentiments expressed by tens of millions of individuals who reside in a nation where over half of the world’s deadliest mass shootings have occurred in the past 50 years and whose citizens are 20 times more likely to die of gun violence than those of other developed nations. 
(H/T to The Onion)

Comment: It seems important to remember that these definitions set the conditions which allow commercial operations to function with none of the usual controls.

These are commercial operations which will take place in residential neighborhoods, and which won't be subject to the health-and-safety rules that govern other commercial lodging providers.  

Because it's the unincorporated County, many of these structures will be served by untested private wells, and won't have access to fire hydrants  --  if they catch fire, they will burn down;  with luck, they won't start wildfires that will burn their neighbors too.

There seems to be quite a lobby for these "shadow" businesses, and that lobby seems to be making itself heard behind the scenes.  These negotiations have the potential to make life both unpleasant and dangerous for normal families who just want to live quietly and safely in their own homes. 

Please, move cautiously, Commissioners!

Comment: The headline says: "The one housing-market fix that Canada hasn't tried".

Are you kidding me?

There are multiple policy approaches that Canada hasn't tried.

One of them goes like this:  To solve its affordability problem, Vancouver could make muscular use of property taxes. You now work at a local job and pay income tax? Terrific, your yearly property taxes are low. You worked, at some point in your life, ten or more years anywhere in Canada paying income tax? Terrific, your yearly property taxes are low. 

But, you do not work at a local job, and you have not worked ten years anywhere in Canada? Sorry, your property taxes are 20 percent the value of the property per year, for a typical Vancouver house that is 350,000 dollars a year, and that money goes to Victoria and Ottawa as income tax proxy-equivalents. 

That is how you address affordability in Vancouver. You address the main component driving the DISTORTING demand side, namely the flood of overseas money.

Comment: As with so many things there is a long history of this one, one that dates back decades.

Through the 1970's and especially the 1980's and 1990's the old Ontario Hydro built up a lot of debt caused by a combination of political gaming and mismanagement.  By the late 1990's there was over $30B in debt in Ontario Hydro, which the Province was 100% responsible for but it was kept off Provincial books.

Mike Harris' PC government tried to fix up this mess and the disaster that was Ontario Hydro.  Part of that was to split Ontario Hydro into multiple companies with appropriate levels of debt assigned to each, which is where OPG and Hydro One (among others) came from.  However ~$20B of the ~$38B of the Ontario Hydro debt belong with the Provincial government (keeping in mind the Provincial government was 100% liable for all the debt). YES!! YES!!

I came across a reply by CaeLew the other day to a comment something like "A central tenet of Catholicism is that doctrine does not change."  She profoundly rebutted "A central tenet of the universe is that everything evolves." 

In a nutshell that captures what I believe the Holy Spirit has been screaming at us for the last couple of hundred years, and most dramatically since the discovery of the big bang one hundred years ago. Virtually all previous human thought, and most emphatically all previous theology, assumed the exact opposite--a stable universe and an even more stable arena in which humans, regardless when they live, work out what is true.

Ultimately, I believe we must accept that revelation itself is not only ONGOING (in the minimalist sense that the Holy Spirit continues to attempt to influence us, although profoundly hampered by freedom to not listen), but actually EVOLVES (what she says changes over time, adjusting to our capacity to understand).

Comment: I don't know what happened with the S.O.P.'s ( Standard Operating Procedures ) that were useful.  I ran a warehouse that imported and shipped natural herbal formulations inside Canada.  When the produce was ready for shipment, the parent company or manufacturer  had to provide the lab tests from their end, send the QC scientists, and Independent lab owner in this case registered with the Federal government.   Our shipment went into a quarantine state and the QC would appear, choose bottles at random, test them and compare the result to what the manufacturer claimed.  It always matched.  This procedure was registered and filed with Health Canada to ensure correct and safe products.  Some how that has been circumvented and there is a lot of amnesia about this.  Then again, the manufacturers are wanting to be seen to do the right thing, but a shame they had to be caught to do it...if they were't then they would have carried on...

Comment: Since its inception more than 100 years ago, the Cook Inlet salmon fisheries have focused primarily on sockeye salmon for harvest, as it generates 90 - 95% of the revenues. The primary rivers for sockeye in Cook Inlet are the Kenai and Kasilof Rivers. According to ADFG, these stocks are two of the most exploited sockeye stocks in Alaska, with harvest rates at or above Maximum Sustained Yield (MSY). The "millions" of salmon left unexploited are pinks and chums, which processors don't want during the sockeye salmon season. 

Martin complains that the BOF process is not transparent. If you want to see the types of proposals UCIDA has submitted to the BOF since 2003, check out the BOF website, where there is an archive of every proposal and all the ADFG science reports.   

You can look at their many, many proposals to restrict and strangle the dipnet and sport fisheries in Cook Inlet. It is very transparent what type of group he represents - everyone else is the problem except UCIDA.

Comment: I understand your reaction and I feel your pain.  I was you in 1987 - no chance we could really afford what was on offer.   30 years later I have to respectfully inform you that this is just the way it is.  I've lived through multiple cycles:  1987, the 1989 crash, NDP recession of the 90's and recovery, and 2007/2008 great recession spillover. 

Bottom line is that Toronto is NOT just any other city.  It's unique in Canada.  The prices here are what they are due to a unique mix of factors and pressures based on a real economy and desire for people to live here.  Similar types of factors that drive similar types of prices in New York, London, San Francisco, high-end Chicago and LA.   Like those places, prices will certainly ebb and flow with government regulation changes, the overall economy, inflation, employment, interest rates and great recessions.  However, over time, the desire to live in a place (that is, actual supply and demand) is the only factor driving the housing market.

Comment: The mature view is that the US, on the one hand, and Mexico and Canada, on the other, benefit from NAFTA and would benefit further from updates reflecting the needs of economies that have evolved over the past 3 decades. Likewise, all would suffer a brutal transition and loss of many long term benefits if NAFTA was terminated.

These will be tough negotiations and may be punctuated by one side or the other suspending negotiations or threatening to terminate NAFTA.  However, there are good reasons to believe that after prolonged negotiations a viable compromise solution will emerge.

The key is for Canada and Mexico to remain steadfast and reasonable and not allow themselves to become overawed or bullied into accepting unreasonable concessions to the US or into foregoing reasonable US concessions as part of the final bargain.

Comment: Well, why not a few heart grown saints!

Consider St. Patrick who got there by public acclaim rather than a nod from hierarchy.
And I have encountered my own street saints. Like St. Mario, a homeless fellow whose poverty of spirit taught me volumes using very few words. 

Of late we seem to have watched the demise of many a hero... Lance Armstrong is an example of the myth and the man. So many of us wanted him to be "real" that the betrayal fell hard on many.  Discernment comes late sometimes...

Probably my best read on saint selection came from Lawrence Cunningham's Trilogy. In Vol. 1 The Catholic Heritage he takes the time to track through the patterns of lineage, of the bloodlines of saints and the assumptions made by merely being born into a "saintly" line. 

Perhaps what we are being shown is that our 'saints' like beauty are often recognized by the beholder and are gift designed to fit a place in the heart to bare fruit nurtured by the grace of God.

Comment: This is a strong, clear Op-Ed. I wish the R-G editorial board would officially come out in favor of the Clean Energy Jobs Bill too. It's not perfect, but it's worlds better than what's being pursued in most of the other states. Everyone reading this should call-write-email his/her state reps in favor of it. 

My only reservation concerns the extent to which the Bill would preserve/honor the "Oregon constitutional requirement that revenue generated from vehicle fuel must go to roads." 

Monies generated from carbon fees SHOULD go into encouraging and constructing alternatives to roads. cars, and trucks. It would be self-defeating to use the market to discourage carbon fuel use while also encouraging carbon-powered vehicle use. 

At the very least, greater provision should be made for rewarding buyers, users, and builders of electric powered vehicles.

Under Chip's tenure, there was never a looming concern about effort, intensity, preparation or ongoing lack of discipline. Helfrich also isn't recruiting as well. Only one of his four recruiting classes was ranked by Rivals in the top 20 (#17 in 2015). By contrast, three of Chip's four recruiting classes were ranked in the top 20; one ranked #9 (2011). 

All the money in the world from Knight isn't going to change the present reality of Ducks football -- it needs a wholesale change from the top down. It's not a "special" place, immune from all of the problems and shortcomings at other major college football programs. Look at what Michigan had to do for several years to get to where they are. Look at LSU, Auburn, etc. Change is inevitable, so fighting it or dismissing problems as "flukey" is irrational and detrimental.

Comment: Allow me to take issue with one presumed advantage you describe: the advantage of drawing from their own experience in marriage counseling. To some extent the potential (note potential)  for objectivity by the celibate counselor can be an advantage in pre- and post marriage counseling. Non-professional counselors (most clergy, I contend) tend to bring their biases to discussions. If one is a "directive" style one is simply stating the role, relationship and specific denominational obligations of marriage. If one is "non-directive" one is ensuring that the parties are informed and that it is effectively mediated between the parties so that they arrive at a mutual conclusion. So the criterion is professionalism not whether one is married or single. Who bases their selection of "pamphlet", psychologist, psychiatrist on the basis of marriage status?
That being said I admire your openness and agree with your final conclusion: choice.

Comment: That's not entirely correct.
There are actually several categories of manslaughter.
Unlawful act — when a person commits a crime that unintentionally results in the death of another person OR
Criminal negligence — when the homicide was the result of an act or a failure to act that showed wanton or reckless disregard for the lives of others

When I looked up the law, I saw no reference specifically to an intent to do harm.  If I fired a gun off in the air and the bullet struck and killed someone, I may have not intended to do harm, but it's still manslaughter.  In this case, the driver's careless act may not have intended to cause harm but, again, somebody was killed.  That could easily translate to criminal negligence.

My point is that options exist under the Code as written.  The fact that the crown chose not to pursue those options is on them.

Comment: Social Security has not ended elderly homelessness and poverty.  There is still plenty of that.  Social security was established in 1935 to protect widows, orphans and the elderly.  Since then more categories of beneficiaries have been created.  While people live much longer, the minimum age to receive benefits has not risen.  Social Security and programs of the like have ballooned with no means to pay for them.

In 2009 the Office of the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration calculated an unfunded obligation of $15.1 trillion for the Social Security program. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Security_(United_States)#History  Other sources put it higher.

Social Security ended the family's obligation to care for their own.  Now people don't save for their own retirement or their parents' care.  They leave it to 'others' to do it for them.

We need to reform Social Security and similar programs.

Comment: The key word in our state Constitution is "provision", and "ample provision" at that.
What we continue to fret over is better termed as "ensure success", and a huge and bloated system attempting to solve that has resulted in a generation of kids our businesses won't hire, and even speculate to foreign education systems to provide.
Our Constitution doesn't say "ensure success", a concept only a student can address.
Our P-12 teachers are well educated through a tough system, and meet ongoing requirements which are, if anything, too stringent. We can trust them to do their jobs.
Colleges/universities who whine about kids not being "ready" would do better to flunk them then to address readiness. At their level the kid is an adult, and needs to have already realized their responsibility. 
Second chance remedial should be its own thing, probably best handled through private business, who as paid services can better deal with those who lag behind and/or choose to game the system.

Comment: "Gouging the citizens"? You do know, don't you, that having no state income tax, and having a PFD program, are both very unusual benefits that most Americans don't have?
We've been living in a fool's paradise for many years, thinking that oil revenue would always continue at high levels. Having no state income tax, plus having an un-capped PFD, is just not sustainable. Thinking that we can somehow squeeze more revenue out of oil and gas resources in the face of the current and likely future market conditions is a fantasy. 
It won't be fun to find ourselves in the situation of paying state income or sales taxes, but it's how most states operate. As to the un-capped PFD, we just can't continue to see it as sacrosanct.

Comment: There's undeniably some truth to that, but your claim about it being a 95% decline isn't supported by that link, and is completely refuted by the current data. http://monarchwatch.org/blog/uploads/2016/02/monarch-population-figure-monarchwatch-2016.png

As the author mentions, year-to-year changes can vary significantly due to factors like the weather, which is why they've provided averages. It's much more accurate to say that monarch populations have declined 43%. Mind you, I'm not saying that that's somehow "acceptable", but at this point herbicide-tolerant crops have essentially reached saturation. If there is further habitat loss, it has to be due to some other factor.

It's also worth pointing out the opposite side of the issue. The adoption of herbicide-tolerant crops has reduced the use of tilling as a weed-control method. That, in turn, reduces erosion which can be extremely harmful to the environment.

Comment: Hello Machine,

Your post is not based on the reality of the landscape.

You need to ask a simpler question and decide where you stand.

If every millionaire on the planet started bidding tomorrow on houses in Halifax, then within a few years a small house in Halifax would cost seven million dollars. Nearly all of them owned by millionaires with jobs overseas.

The question is: Are you okay with that? Are you okay with local workers with jobs in Halifax no longer being able to afford a house there? 

If you are okay with that, fine, say so, declare that you think houses should be treated as commodities like big twenty-pound bars of gold, only the rich own them.

Your cheerleading chant about free markets accomplishes nothing.

Comment: Experience has shown that tax credits are an extremely poor way to influence behaviour, to the point of being next to useless.  So I would argue that almost all of the deductions and refunds were put in place for crass attempts to win votes.

The one obvious exception would be the dividend tax credit which is purely a means of tax equality.  Wages and the like are paid with pre-tax money from corporations while dividends are paid with after-tax money from corporations.  The dividend tax credit is simply a credit for taxes already paid at the corporate level.  The calculation is a bit tricky, but the end result is that total taxation is the same between income paid as wages or as dividends.

Comment: Science and history reveal the real world, Horn, more completely than individual experience. And you're missing the point about the survival of human societies: modern society can thrive in extreme conditions only through intensive energy expenditures. To be comfortable in extreme conditions requires even more energy use.

You might consider what the population of the planet would be if fossil fuels did not warm and cool us, or if climatic disruption made industrial-scale agriculture impossible, or if tropical disease vectors, encouraged, by warming, suddenly showed up in densely populated northern cities, or if wide swaths of densely populated coast went under saltwater. Yes, it is "the church of God," and many of its core beliefs, teachings and practices can be called divine and trustworthy. At the same time, it is an institution led by men, some better, some worse, some wise, some foolish, all imperfect and subject to weaknesses of many kinds. Human nature is indeed a very important subject, and that includes sexuality as a part of it. Christianity has a distinctive concept of that nature, and of what a truly pious or saintly relationship of the human with God should look like. Just as an FYI, when I'm trying to read threads, I find it quite useful to have the name of the person to whom i'm replying available, for several reasons.  Obviously, many of us who have been here a while know a lot about where we each come from.  In this new system, we've given the first few lines of the post, but often the response is to something further into that prior post.  With this system, we've gotta scroll back up, and reread the original posts to find what they're talking about.   And history suggests this will get even more complex, for thoughts can develop over multiple posts in a thread.  So for me, having this isn't about "voting," as much as it is a matter of maintaining a high quality of dialog.  Not having that ability (either to see who a poster was responding to, or for that matter, what they were responding to) without having to search and connect dots seems odd.

Maybe as this all goes forward, it'll all get to make more sense for me.

Comment: The pen that collapsed off the San Juans held just one-third as many fish as the pen proposed for our shores.  And the aftermath has been a reminder  that the Salish Sea is really quite a small aquatic neighborhood.

I'm glad that we will finally be taking a serious look at the risks of open-water farming of exotic salmon species.  Pen collapse is not the biggest problem with fish farming  --  there are also the issues of salmon pathogens and parasites constantly released into the whole aquatic flow, along with the antibiotics and pesticides used to keep them down, and quite a few other proven dangers to our native fish.

I hope WA State and Clallam County both take a serious look at all the hazards associated with open-water fish farming.  A handful of jobs is not worth the ruination of our waters.  If fish farming can be made safer for native fish, then we should require the industry to make it so.  If it can't, then we should refuse to host it here.

Comment: Religious law is included in the definition of “legal system” in dictionaries. Canon law does not cease to be a legal system because there is something about it you don’t like. I don’t particularly like capital punishment, but those States which allow it do not cease to have legal systems as a result. Like civil law, canon law has sets of rules that provide minimum standards of conduct, the breach of which involves punishment. A clear distinction is drawn in both systems between moral obligations and legal ones. They both have means of promulgation, interpretation and enforcement through courts.  They have systems of study and conferring of degrees. There is no need to “ban” canon law where it requires disobedience to civil law, because civil law effectively does that. If canon law requires bishops to break the civil law, they will still be punished by the civil legal system if they do. Bishop Pican in France is a good example.

Comment: You advocated removing dams that posed no danger to downstream lives and property except in the case of "the Big One" earthquake, yet the last such quake, in the year 1700 didn't so much as leave a sand layer at Salt Creek, such as was found at Neah Bay. The tsunami had apparently come in from the SW, up the Wa'atch and washed the village out into the strait. Most people survived by jumping into their canoes. The wave evidently parted around Cape Flattery and met itself at Neah, creating a standing wave that cast a layer of sand 100' up the hillside. No such layer is found at Salt Creek, nor are there stories of a tsunami inundating villages farther East.

Yet you feared dams falling down more than trees? For this nonsensical fear we lost flood control, two excellent reservoirs and sport fishing in two scenic lakes. The lower dam simply needed the log-raft plug dredged and the river would have cut a new channel under the dam that eventually fish would have been able to negotiate.

Comment: "I am still, at 70, a candidate for lung cancer."

This is true, but your risk has been cut at least in half!

That said, lung cancer is not, nor has it ever been, then greatest health risk with smoking. Of the major medical issues that smoking can cause, the most likely one is cardiovascular disease. Quitting smoking can reduce this risk almost to pre-smoking levels. Lung cancer and emphysema approximately tie for the #2 spot at a bit less than 10% each for people who smoke 1-3 packs per day (and, from what I hear from sufferers and doctors, you'd probably prefer the cancer to the emphysema.)

Comment: Actually, what they did in Australia was forced confiscation under the guise of a buy back.

In Australia, you have to apply for a license to buy a firearm  You can only get a license by proving the need for the firearm.  If you are a recreational shooter, you have to belong to a club and use the club's firearms for six months before applying for a license.  Self protection is not a valid reason for a license.

Once you get your license, you cannot purchase:

Any form of semi automatic firearm, including 22's.  Any pump action shotguns.  Handguns are extremely restricted.

Comment: CivilizedDawn: "Either that, or you can't do basic math."
So let's do the math. 

Assuming 40hr/wk @ $14/hr, employees are making $560/wk minus taxes. But they're probably putting in 60hr weeks, for $980/wk.
I'm not sure if seasonal employees count, but as I recall with more than 50 full time employees ACA requires health insurance.

The work is seasonal. Mr. Medrano does keep 1/3 of his staff for winter work. If he kept all his staff and let them sit idle for 8 mo/yr, their effective salaries for hours worked would be $42/hr+benefits.
 
I'm not sure about this industry in today's market, but when I ran a machine shop in the 70s, my cost per employee was about 2Xsalary (taxes, benefits, administration, etc.). My billing rate added equipment (depreciation, energy, supplies, space, etc.) charges and material costs (w/shipping & storage). Yes, we also added a little profit, something like 5%. Add it all up and pray that your numbers are less than your competitors'.

Comment: Regardless of whether it would improve Junior's approval rating, the supreme law of the land says otherwise.

Once a refugee claimant is in Canada then the Charter is engaged and "fundamental justice" (or version of due process) is required and that has come to mean an oral hearing on the merits of the claim before the Refugee Protection Division per the 1985 SCOC decision in Singh v Canada [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177.  The government exploited a technical loophole in the Singh decision and designated the USA as a Safe Third Country but that only works at the Port of Entry because technically those claimants are not yet IN Canada.

The Harper government recognized this legal fact and that is why they  continued to process claimants who entered Canada illegally or perhaps more accurately irregularly in that s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act exempts refugees from being prosecuted and punished for what would be for other migrants an illegal entry.

Comment: Ideally, we would use a flat tax for income taxation, since it's the fairest form of taxation (everyone pays the same rate).  But I do recognize that that would simply be too onerous for those currently paying very little and struggling to pay even that.  So I'm willing to forgo SOME fairness and recognize that some disproportionality (that's a better descriptive word that progressive, IMO) in the income tax rates.  

But I do think they we need to make them flatter than they are now.  I'd actually start by adding a national sales tax (maybe 5%).  Consumption taxes are better than income taxes anyway.  And flatter.  And less likely to be cheated on since it's a ton of small transactions (not worth making the effort to cheat) like it is on one big transaction (your annual tax return).  That would allow income taxes to come down by maybe 30%, which could be used to drastically lower US corporate income tax rates, and lower the individual income tax rates.

Comment: An award for courage under pressures we'll never know, for leadership, and for talent. Congratulations. And did I say for courage? 

Folks in the future will ask, "You mean Tom Fox's search for truth wasn't always accepted and supported by the Church hierarchy, even though he was often prophetic?"   

Consider: Bishop John England, for whom the award is named, in 1822 USA  defended the separation of Church and state. My kids today say, "Duh!" But in Bishop England's day that concept was not only risky for any Catholic, it--along with a free press and other heresies of "Americanism" --was declared gravely sinful, disloyal, and heretical. 

Truth, as Tom says, is a Catholic journalist's sacred mission, even when--especially when-- aggressively seeking it is declared un-Catholic and, yes, literally sinful. May truth always be OUR mission as well.  And may we always celebrate a Fox-NCR virtue often solely ascribed to the Catholic Right: "Contemporary Courage to be Authentically Catholic."

Health care is something everyone needs, sooner or later, and unless you've managed to save up tens or hundreds of thousands toward the day you get sick or injured (how much have YOU saved, Ronni?), you will need health insurance or Medicare or Medicaid to pay for it. If you go to the emergency room it will cost ten time a much, and if you can't pay, someone else (me) will get part of the bill. So if we have single payer we all pay into taxes; if we have private insurance, then, since everyone eventually gets sick, everyone has to buy insurance. Get it?

Comment: I disagree, James.  The U.S. has long memorialized its own losses resulting from U.S. wars with foreign powers, even when other countries (both allies & enemies) endured FAR greater losses in the same wars.
.
Americans, understandably, memorialized U.S. servicemen killed in WWI/WWII but most were indifferent to Russia's MILLIONS of fatalities (dramatically higher than the U.S.'s death toll) in the Allies' defeat of Germany or, say, the high percentage of Australia's men who voluntarily fought & then died to defeat Germany (& Japan) that was greater than the U.S.'s percentage of its men who fought & died in the same wars.  And, understandably, the U.S. memorialized Americans killed at Pearl Harbor & Normandy Beach, not the far higher numbers of enemy-nation civilians killed in Dresden & Hiroshima.
.
IMHO, death-toll disparities would not deter Americans from memorializing (and not dissuade historians from writing about) a U.S. city nuked by N.Korea's first, and LAST, nuclear strike.

Comment: Your argument is the fallacy of false dichotomy. We know nothing unless we have data. Let's break this down.
First, what is your criteria for valid data? Traffic? Accidents? If we have valid data, what numbers represent success/failure? Is a 10% increase in traffic along side streets a failure? 
By "data" I assume you mean numbers. What of evidence from users? We know the neighborhood association has deemed it a favorable outcome. Is this an indicator of success? If we found side streets through this neighborhood had increased traffic and yet the association said they are in favor of the project, is that not success?
Shall we dismiss other sources of data? Some business owners have come to favor the project. Probably some don't. Very few allowed the city to look at financials. What do we make of these facts?
I think we can make some assumptions about the success without your claim that we need certain data to know anything. I will state the successes are greater than before.

Comment: How is more collegiality among celibate, male bishops going to fix anything? Without listening to the people in the pews, it means nothing.

We don't know Jesus' politics. Possibly he was a rebel (per book 'Zealot') fighting a class war against the Romans and their collaborators: the upper class Jews and the Temple priesthood. I think rather Jesus was a reformer, not a warrior. I will guess the Gospel's money changers symbolize taxation of the poor if the Romans taxed the Temple (why wouldn't they?) and all donations to it had to be in the currency preferred by the Romans. Those making donations were required to bear the cost of money changing?? A simple solution to taxation at a single collection point -- the Temple -- would have been decentralization. Did Jesus think of this solution? Years later, the Jews did in fact disperse because the Temple was destroyed. But there was already a trend towards synagogues? Jesus paid a tax to the Temple (subject to Roman tax?) but under protest.

Comment: Inflatable canoes aren't rafts. Inflatable canoes are fairly easy for novice paddlers to flip in class 3 rapids whereas rafts of a similar or even substantially shorter length are not.

Running whitewater in any kind of canoe or kayak without dry suits is not recommended in near freezing glacial rivers. In a very short amount of time in glacial melt waters, swimmers become hypothermic and lose all strength.

Allowing two clients who had not yet paddled together run the rapids on a river running high in an inflatable canoe wasn't the final bad decision.

Having a guide in a kayak to chase down swimmers is far better than having a guide in a raft loaded with gear trying to perform a rescue. The raft loaded with gear couldn't possibly keep up with the swimmers drifting quickly downstream.

It's always amazing how fast bad things can happen on Alaskan rivers. Sometimes it takes only one mistake for things to turn deadly but more often it's a series of mistakes that lead up to tragedy.

Comment: The economic damage is negligible when we're energy-independent, producing our own fossil fuels rather than having to import them.  We spend over $300 billion/yr on oil.  When most of that was to OPEC countries, that money left our economy.  When we spend the same amount on domestically produced oil, it stays in our economy.  The environmental impact has been grossly exaggerated.  The CO2 emissions improve the environment; it is not a pollutant.

The pollutant from coal-fired power plants was SO2, a highly reactive emission that quickly combined with particulates in the air to form "brown clouds."  Clean coal technology eliminates nearly all of that.  Again, the CO2 it emits isn't a pollutant.

About 60% of our electricity in Colorado still comes from coal-fired plants.  Where's the pollution?  Our cost of electricity is among the lowest in the nation, and the nation's is one third of Germany's, where they rely more on solar and wind than we do.

The various "independent" organizations that are supposed to look out for ratepayers, system viability, etc, are not independent at all: they are merely arms of the government. They implement policy as ordered by the Energy Minister.

Policy is designed for short-term political gain, or crafted with a kind of grandiose hubris disconnected from reality. The people in charge are politicians with little relevant experience (consider: there've been _10_ different Ministers of Energy during the Liberals' term)… and no grasp of the facts on the ground.

The only check on this process is voter anger. But the issues are complex, cause & effect are separated by many years, and blame can always be shifted to the past.

This is how you end up with banana-republic-grade institutions.

Comment: Although I couldn't find the 20-year old decisions in Doug Collins' case, I found this additional info:

"In 1997, the tribunal dismissed one complaint against something Collins wrote about the Jews. But in 1999, after a second complainant cited four of his columns, the tribunal decided that, taken together, they portrayed Jews as selfish, greedy and manipulative. They reinforced negative stereotypes and were "likely to increase the risk to Jewish people of being exposed to hatred or contempt." 

"The tribunal ordered Collins and the North Shore News to pay $2,000 to the complainant, Harry Abrams, an advertising man. That ruling was under appeal when Collins died in October at the age of 81."

So, still no fine.  You may think the difference between a fine and an order to pay damages to the plaintiff is a  "technicality"  but it is not.  One is the state against an individual; the other is a civil dispute between two individuals, similar to a libel case.

And Ezra - nothing at all.
