Comment: "It just seems the left doesn't want to engage in debate"

It's not that the left doesn't want to engage in debate. It's that the left wonders what the end condition of the "debate" is. When there is objective measurement that global temperatures are steadily rising, and that glaciers and ice sheets are melting, it seems like at least the first part of the debate (whether the planet is warming) is pretty well settled. We don't know exactly how much is human-caused, and how much is natural, but we have a decent understanding of the mechanisms that cause warming, and the only responsible course of action is to do what we can to slow or reverse them.

Meanwhile, climate change deniers would rather stretch the "debate" out in perpetuity. But this is very much a "ticking clock" scenario. If it isn't real, but we act on it anyway, then the worst case scenario is that we <gasp!> reduce pollution unnecessarily. If it is real, and we fail to reverse it, then we likely get wiped out.

Comment: What you call "a stretch too far" I call a simple matter of fact. It only requires the most basic familiarity with the scientific method to  know that any theory which rejects empiricism is already, by definition, a pseudo-science since empiricism is an absolutely uncompromisable foundation of the difference between science and pseudo-science.
Ever since Obama signed the stimulus bill in 2009 there has been non-stop predictions by Austrian School subscribers that hyperinflation in the USA is imminent. Not only did it not happen, throughout the great recession the *opposite* problem had to be constantly combated: the USA was at constant risk of deflation triggering a depression. The exact opposite of what the Austrian school predicted.
A scientific theory which is so thoroughly disproven about something would correct that prediction, or be abandoned entirely. They have done neither because they reject empirical data as a test of of the theory.

Comment: Debt dynamics aren't your strong point.

He inherited debt of 42% of GDP, and left a level of 66%

When you inherit an economy that has had as much debt thrown at it as Canada had,  and the deficits are exploding, just wrestling those deficits from disastrous to merely bad is a major achievement. Our modern understanding of debt vulnerability is that it is the speed of accumulation that is the biggest problem, and PET's runaway deficits of his last 3 years in power put the economy into ER surrounded by crash carts.

Mulroney turned a 2.7% Primary deficit into a 1.8% surplus, and cut PET's 8.1% Deficit into only 4.4% within 5 years - that is hard stuff outside an IMF program, and only slightly behind Irelands adjustment between 2011 and 2013 . 

Could he have got that down to 4 - 3.5%? Possibly, but that degree of adjustment, when unemployment was so high, and real wages falling would have been brutal. He would have been better admitting defeat and restructuring the debt.

Comment: Capital gains are only taxed when a stock or property is sold.  When the capital gains tax went down to 50% of the capital gain, the amount of taxes collected skyrocketed because investors were more willing to sell stocks and buy others.

Also, capital gains generally come from being able to save up some money and investing.  We should be encouraging people to do this not taking up to half the profits from investments away.  Finally, dividends are already taxed as corporate income, so the lower tax rate is so they aren't double taxed.

Comment: The police are overworked and yet do a job so difficult that few who comment here would ever consider that as a career. I am not excusing those who gather downtown, but here is one story.
Consider "Ted" (not his real name) who I met in my neighborhood when he was 15. "Ted" seemed kind of lost, so I took mentored him (when people did not worry so much). We went on a few excursions, like to the Air Show in Beaverton. I lost contact with Ted.
Until I saw him downtown at the bus station. Now in his early 20s, he had a cadre of "friends," made people laugh, and looked stoned. I did not approach him. Would you?
Later, I would see him at the bus station and in our neighborhood, now with a wife and child. He'd do some work around the house. I'd talk to him and give him some cash. He looked more stoned than ever.
Now at 36, he no longer has the child. He looks terrible, and lives on the street with his wife. He just came to me for money. I said no more until he stops drugs.
Who do you blame?

Comment: First, we can dispense with the "started" crap Al keeps trying to twist it into.  We're talking about when the US actually engaged in fighting, and who the US president was that sent them.

Clearly that was under Wilson (D) for WWI, FDR (D) for WWII, Truman (D) for Korea, and JFK/LBJ (D) for Vietman.  Eisenhower didn't sent any troops to fight in Vietman, he sent a team of advisors, not combat troops.

Obviously every war has a history behind in, and escalating tensions that led to war.  That's obvious.  We could spend days dissecting the history leading up to each war.  But that's not the point here.  We were simply talking about who was US president when we started engaging in combat.

Of the major wars, that's 4 by D's I listed above, and 3 by R's since (Desert Storm, Afganistan, Iraq).  Now if you want to start counting smaller conflicts too, the list is longer than what you listed. Like (for example) Kosovo, Haiti, and Somalia just under Clinton alone.

Comment: Interesting take on the psychology of bullies.  What has been learned over decades of study of those who bully shows a few different factors. (1) Bullies are insecure about themselves, deeply so, and adopt a stance of dominating others to avoid feeling weak or ineffectual themselves; (2) their major defense is "do to others before they do it to you;" (3) A sadistic anger is at the root of their emotional disturbance; (4) they operate in a culture of support for their victimization of others, see others who do not oppose them as being weak and deserving of the abuse, and (4) gain temporary relief of their inner tensions by abusing others and making others fear them.  Add into the mix the internet that allows for anonymous attacks on the integrity of others, and a national, powerful figure who operates on such a basis themselves and encourages others to do the same (or worse), and you have a hostile and expanding culture of hate and oppression.  Bullies need control far more than pity.

Comment: You're assuming too much of the Electoral College. The result and the intent are not the same. The Constitution of the United States talks of no such thing, only electors, who were the interface between the national (federal) government and each of the states. It was up to the states to determine who would be an elector and how they would vote. The problem this election is that all but two states award electors to the winner in a winner-take-all scheme. They started doing this in the 1824 election to help their favorite candidate. Once a few states started doing it, the rest followed. If states awarded electors proportionally to candidates, the Electoral College result would closely match the popular vote. 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Popular_Vote_Interstate_Compact

Comment: Hurley v. Irish American Gay, Lesbian, and Bisexual Group of Boston
(1995), is a landmark decision of the Supreme Court of the United States regarding free speech rights, specifically the rights of groups to determine what message their activities convey to the public. The Court ruled that private organizations, even if they were planning on and had permits for a public demonstration, were permitted to exclude groups if those groups presented a message contrary to the one the organizing group wanted to convey.

Comment: An honest critique of your argument might require a more nuanced understanding of the historical timeline and context of events:
A preamble, in practice, is typically an ambiguous statement of noble platitudes and banalities chosen more for poetic license than as applicable rule of law.

 Modern Americans often roll our eyeballs when we read that Jefferson penned a Declaration of Independence stating “all men are created equal” while his slaves were toiling on his tobacco plantation.

The Constitution was written 136 years before any New Deal redistribution schemes were created; there wasn’t any peacetime federal income tax until after 1916. To say that a 1787 preamble is a blank check to categorize modern entitlement programs as constitutional rights is an absurdity that no credible court would propose.

Comment: Again, your relative is in a "seniors' residence", not a nursing home. There is a big difference. 

You can't just move into a nursing home. It requires that a doctor signs off stating that you are eligible. Then you fill out a form stating (in order) the nursing home you want to move into. Usually you can list 5, but you don't have to. The best nursing homes, at least in Toronto, often have 4 - 5 year waitlists. It doesn't matter if you're in a flop house or a nice home, the rates are basically the same. 

You can choose to move into a seniors residence, which is similar to moving into an apartment that offers 3 meals/day, light housekeeping and activities. Seniors residences aren't required to have medical staff, although some do. You are required to pay for extra care and it can really add up.

Two working parents is a very new development. One used to be able to do it, and it was one parent working a job, not a six-figure position. It went from one working partner, to two, then the savings got consumed, now everyone uses credit. This trajectory, though it has opened doors for the careers of women, is not a success. It's run out the money just about as far as it can go. Big Government cannot fix this, because Big Government is the problem.

Comment: Speakplain907, I learned this many years ago and I hold it as one of the key truths that exist: 

You cannot stop any problem from the supply side. 

What that refers to is the supply/demand curve from basic economics. Where there is a demand, there will be a supply to meet that demand. All we try to do (and fail every day) is to limit the supply side. We prohibit. We fine. We dump out bottles. We fail, every day. 

You cannot lock it down because someone will come up with more novel ways to sneak it in. Guaranteed. The only way to ever fight a dangerous substance is to fight it on the demand side. As long as rural villagers need alcohol, they will get it. End of story. 

So you can label a community "dry" as much as you want and pretend that accomplishes anything. It hasn't, doesn't, and won't accomplish anything. You can *only* convince people they do not want alcohol, either through providing massive resources for counseling OR providing a safer alternative (cough cough).

Comment: 2/2 continuation
An anecdote: In South Africa - the Anglican Bishops met with their first black Bishop to discuss what position they would take on the new marriage laws being imposed by the Nationalist government. They were all agreed that apartheid was morally wrong and would stand shoulder to shoulder with people of all and mixed races etc etc. They then broke up for lunch and went to the restaurant next door - all except 2 of them (the black bishop who was not allowed into a whites only restaurant, and one other who accompanied him). They went without lunch. None of the others were aware of their privilege or behaviour ... until afterwards. It was this bishop who told the story - without rancour, with good humour and with forgiveness - what a witness to Christ's grace. 
I repeat this story, not to point fingers at the Anglicans but to illustrate how easy it is to be 'righteous' in our decisions and yet unaware of our own collusion in racism (or any other privileged '-ism'.

Comment: I strongly disagree with much of what you have written, but because of space I'll address only one item: retention. That subject has been contentious for a very, very long while. Capable researchers have tracked students who were and were not retained in an effort to nail down whether retention generally improves or hurts achievement. Others have collected all the relevant studies and calculated what the universe of information tells us about retention - meta studies. The quality of studies does vary, and results vary a bit too, but the conclusion is clear: retention almost always impairs achievement, and seldom improves it. Why? The answer seems to be that for our students social effects usually are more damaging than any benefits that might come from repeating a grade. Label a student as a failure, and he'll do everything he can to live up to the label. One good reference: Thomas Holmes & Ken Matthews at http://rer.sagepub.com/content/54/2/225.abstract.

Comment: Today, vehicles may be more fuel efficient than they were in the past, but they are much more expensive to maintain. The engine is turned sideways and the engine compartment is crowded so that it is difficult to access many of the parts without removing other parts. Same for the dashboard instruments.  For example, in the past, if your turn signal flasher burned out, you could buy a new one for about $10 and easily replace it yourself.  Now the turn signal flasher "unit" is integrated. The part itself costs about $100 and you have to go to the auto dealer to have them lift out the dashboard in order to install the new replacement part (labour cost $100 to $500 depending on the skill of the mechanic in undestanding how to do the job efficiently. ) There are certain brands of foreign made cars that need fewer repairs, so they have a lower "total cost of ownership".

Comment: On a 20 to 100-year scale, N2O has approximately 300x the greenhouse gas warming potential that CO2 does, on an equivalent volume (or molar) basis. So it would be priced at approximately that factor higher on a molar basis.

However it is only present at a concentration less than 1/1000 that of CO2 (328 ppbv) and is increasing at a rate less than 1/2000 that of CO2 (a little under 1 ppbv/year). So overall N2O pricing would be about 15% that of CO2, if consistently applied.

Methane, with a global warming potential about 25x that of CO2, would fall between the other two gases.

Comment: As a resident and regular patron of over ten years, I can honestly say that I have only had ONE bad experience; and that was years ago. 

I bring my kids, now eight and 13, to the library often, and we never have problems. Perhaps it's because we mind our own business and don't concern ourselves with what others are doing as long as it presents no threat of harm to us. We don't fear diversity, and we don't categorize people as threats simply because they *look* like they have less money or may be homeless. Honestly, we have NEVER witnessed criminal activity or felt afraid while visiting the library.

People need places to go, safe, public places where they can meet without the expectation of spending money. Maybe they're teenagers who just want to hang out with their friends (I remember being a teenager here. We weren't criminals, we were kids). Maybe they are homeless and need a warm place to be. If they aren't breaking any laws, they have just as much right to the space as anyone.

Given the cost of these aircraft, even if it is tens of millions of dollars, it might still be worth it, as opposed to declaring it a total loss and claiming insurance reimbursement.  I don't think Australian military bases would refuse an aircraft in an emergency, but likely have security protocols already in place to ensure that it is not part of a terrorist act, etc.  In the free world, the last ban on civilian aircraft landing in an emergency on an Air Force base was back with Gen. Curtis LeMay and the Strategic Air Command.

Comment: This is as good a way to get rid of weeds as any, but it takes years of constant control to totally eradicate them. Most invasive species are annuals or biennials, which makes you think they'd be easy to get rid of, but their seeds are virile and long-lived. The average musk thistle seed can last for over a decade, while woolly mullein seeds are viable for 80 yrs. Only when you've exhausted the seed bank can you truly claim victory over an invasive weed.

So expect the goats to be back. Why not? They're way cuter (and safer) than a round-up bottle.

However, later reports suggested that he had not carried out a preliminary inquiry as required by canon law, and if that is the case, then he could be disciplined. The same principle would apply to the situation you mention. Canon law is a legal system governed by the rule of law. Disciplinary action is dependent on breach of some canonical obligation and creating offences retrospectively is not consistent with the rule of law.

The 'dismal performance' you cite is a complex issue, and cannot be laid completely at the door of the teaching profession. There are many societal issues that contribute to poor educational outcomes, not to mention the manner those outcomes are measured.

Comment: Are you implying that the age of a law makes it more or less relevant/fair/reasonable? Should we repeal the Rivers and Harbors act because it was passed in 1899? The Public Trust Doctrine provides the anchor for public access to waters and resources, but because some claim it has its roots in the Magna Carta and Justinian Roman Law (both of which are quite less liberal in the "public" element of the doctrine), maybe its time to rethink that.  The General Mining Act of 1872 is often cited as being out of date, without mention that it has seen numerous revisions in its 145 years on the books. Most notably, FLPMA made significant changes in 1981. But golly, that was 35 whole years ago, perhaps you're saying we should chuck those laws too (and ANILCA, while we're at it).

Comment: Children versus grannie as this article implies is a false dichotomy.  It is really those who enjoy the cap on Social Security and Medicare (this year set at $127,200) and the rest of us.  If the cap were removed, both children and grannie could be saved. Follow whose money is being saved rather than generational divides. The divide is between those who pay no more after $127,200 and the rest of us.

Comment: Pollutants, of which smoke is just one, kill people. How much pollutants kill depends on the chemicals they contain, how dense the chemicals per million or even billion parts and how long the exposure. Even nature produces harmful chemicals such as arsenic, which is released in wells in our area. Added to the equation is the fact that some people are more susceptible than others.
To some degree of exactitude, scientists know the death rates for various chemical exposures. This is also true for air pollution.
The pollution index produced by LRAPA might as well be a death index. A certain level of pollution for a certain length of time will kill some people.
The index is an abstraction. A death index would be less so. What if the pollution index was converted to a death index? Would people see pollution differently?
We all to some degree produce pollution that kills. Forest fires are not so much caused by people, but other sources or pollution are.  We are each responsible for our impact

Comment: I guess you have to ask yourself if/when you have an emergency, do you want one or more people nearby to try to help you, even if they are not Certified First Responders? What if they only had some First Aid training years ago? In an emergency, are you wanting anything more than quick help and attempts to help you, or do you want to check with your lawyer first? I was a Certified First Responder on Maui from 1983 to 1996. That was the standard for lifeguards, ambulance drivers, police, fire department, and tour companies, and we were all exempt from liability when responding to emergencies. That should be the same now so, if it isn't, change it back.

Comment: Mr or Ms AKJammer, I'm afraid you missed my point. I'm not asking for an explanation of the deals, nor am I passing judgment on their wisdom or efficacy. All I'm asking is this -- how is it that the GOP has long stood for free markets, yet Trump is now behaving in ways that are antithetical to free market ideology? If the GOP wants to begin coercing companies into not moving their manufacturing abroad, that's fine. But we should acknowledge the practice runs counter to the party's own economic principles. How do you reconcile that cognitive dissonance? That's my question.
